body:
It returns the sum of all output sizes from each layer in your model, which indicates how much memory you need for each pass
Looking into torchsummary.py we can see this

```
for layer in summary:
        # input_shape, output_shape, trainable, nb_params
        line_new = "{:>20}  {:>25} {:>15}".format(
            layer,
            str(summary[layer]["output_shape"]),
            "{0:,}".format(summary[layer]["nb_params"]),
        )
        total_params += summary[layer]["nb_params"]

        total_output += np.prod(summary[layer]["output_shape"])
        if "trainable" in summary[layer]:
            if summary[layer]["trainable"] == True:
                trainable_params += summary[layer]["nb_params"]
        summary_str += line_new + "\n"
```
In the above snippet the total_output stores the sum of all the output sizes from each layer.

```
total_output_size = abs(2. * total_output * 4. /
                            (1024 ** 2.))  # x2 for gradients
summary_str += "Forward/backward pass size (MB): %0.2f" % total_output_size + "\n"
```
Finally it calculates the memory it requires, and displays it
